about: Aspiring Financial Analyst | Financial Modelling | Valuation | Power BI | Advanced Excel
description:
üöÄ Exciting Leadership Change at Air India: Welcoming Sanjay Sharma as the New CFO ‚úàÔ∏è

Air India has announced a significant leadership change! Sanjay Sharma will be stepping into the role of Chief Financial Officer starting June 10, following the retirement of Vinod Hejmadi, who has dedicated over three decades to the airline.

üéâ Meet Sanjay Sharma: A Seasoned Finance Expert

Sharma brings a wealth of experience with over 30 years in Corporate Finance, Investment Banking, and Real Estate. His impressive career includes key roles such as:

- CFO at Tata Projects Limited
- CFO at Tata Realty Infrastructure Limited
- Managing Director, Head of Equity Capital Markets at Deutsche Bank Group
- Various positions at DSP Merrill Lynch Limited in Mumbai and Merrill Lynch Asia Pacific in Hong Kong

üõ´ A Strategic Appointment During Transformative Times

Sanjay Sharma's appointment comes at a pivotal moment for Air India. The airline, now under Tata's ownership since 2022, is embarking on a major transformation plan. This multi-year strategy aims to enhance core operations and customer service, reinforcing Air India's stature in both domestic and international markets.

üîÑ Exciting Developments on the Horizon
As part of its expansion roadmap, Tata is merging its four airlines:
Full-Service Carrier: Combining Vistara (jointly owned with Singapore Airlines) and Air India.
Low-Cost Airline: Integrating Air India Express and AIX Connect.

üåê Air India's Legacy and Future
Founded by JRD Tata in 1932, Air India boasts a rich heritage and extensive international reach. The airline's return to the Tata Group has set the stage for innovative growth and improved services, with Sharma's leadership poised to drive financial strategy and stability.

Join us in welcoming Sanjay Sharma and stay tuned for more updates as Air India soars to new heights! üöÄ‚ú®

description:
üü©‚ñ∂Ô∏è Breaking News: HDFC Bank's Latest Appointment Sets a New Course for Growth

In a strategic move to further strengthen its leadership team, HDFC Bank has made a significant addition. Former NABARD - National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development chairman Harsh Kumar Bhanwala has been appointed an esteemed independent director, signalling a new era of expertise for the renowned financial institution.

Bhanwala's vast experience and exceptional track record make him a valuable asset to HDFC Bank. His appointment, subject to shareholders' approval, is expected to bring fresh insights and perspectives to the board. With a term spanning three consecutive years from January 25, 2024, to January 24, 2027, Bhanwala is set to play a pivotal role in shaping the bank's future.

Joining him in this transformative journey is V Srinivasa Rangan, a distinguished executive with a strong background in housing finance and real estate. Rangan, who previously served as the chief financial officer of Housing Development Finance Corporation Ltd., has been appointed as an executive director. His tenure, starting from November 23, 2023, is anticipated to drive strategic financial decisions and contribute to the bank's growth trajectory.

These appointments reflect HDFC Bank's commitment to fostering a diverse and accomplished leadership team. By bringing in industry veterans like Bhanwala and Rangan, the bank aims to leverage their expertise in navigating complex financial landscapes and fueling innovation.

HDFC Bank's board of directors strongly believes that these strategic additions will further consolidate its position as a leading financial institution equipped to address the evolving needs of its customers and stakeholders.

Stay tuned as HDFC Bank continues to make strides in its mission to redefine the future of banking and deliver exceptional financial services to its valued customers."

description:
Several Fifth Third Bank executives will have new responsibilities after ringing in the new year.

The moves included naming Tim Spence, CEO of the Cincinnati, Ohio, bank, as chairman starting Jan. 2. The bank‚Äôs board members also approved the promotion of Chief Financial Officer Jamie Leonard to chief operating officer.

Replacing Leonard as CFO will be Bryan Preston, who has worked at Fifth Third for nearly two decades and currently serves as the bank‚Äôs treasurer. Brennen Willingham will take the treasurer position after serving as the bank‚Äôs managing director for capital, liquidity and corporate development.

The bank‚Äôs executive leadership under Spence is continuing to execute on a vision for Fifth Third that began during the tenure of former CEO Greg Carmichael, who retired from the bank in July 2022, Piper Sandler analyst Scott Siefers said in an interview.

‚ÄúAcross the board, they get high marks for the transformation that Fifth Third has undergone over the last several years,‚Äù Siefers said. ‚ÄúThe bank has gone in a lot of different directions, which has set the company up for success, no matter the externalities.

about: FCA | DISA | FAFD | Faculty for DISA | ICAI (ITT) | Trained 5000+ students
description:
CA toh ban gayeüë©üèª‚Äçüéì, 
celebrate bhi kar liaüçæ 
per ab kyaü§î??


As a CA myself, I can relate to the feeling that life was simpler during our studies. We had clear goals to work towards and deadlines to meet, which provided a sense of structure and direction.

However, once we've completed the CA course or maybe any other course for that matter, we're faced with a new challenge - navigating our career paths.

After becoming a CA, the world is your oyster, and there are numerous paths you can choose to embark on. Here are a few options to consider:

1. Join a reputed firm: Many newly qualified CAs begin their careers by joining established accounting firms. These firms offer exposure to a wide range of clients and industries, allowing you to gain valuable experience and enhance your skills.

2. Pursue specialization: If you have a specific area of interest within accounting, such as taxation, insolvency, or statutory audit, you can choose to specialize in that field. Acquiring additional certifications or qualifications in your chosen area will not only deepen your knowledge but also make you a sought-after professional in your niche.

3. Start your own practice: If you have an entrepreneurial spirit, starting your own accounting practice can be a fulfilling option. It allows you to be your own boss, take on diverse clients, and build your brand.

4. Explore industry roles: CAs are not limited to working in accounting firms. Many industries value their financial expertise and hire them for various roles such as financial analysts, internal auditors, or financial controllers. This provides an opportunity to work closely with management teams and contribute to the strategic decision-making process.

5. Consider further education: Continuing education is essential to stay ahead in the rapidly changing business landscape. You may choose to pursue advanced degrees such as an MBA or a specialized finance qualification. This can open doors to senior management positions and broader career prospects.

6. Give back to the profession: As a qualified Chartered Accountant, you can contribute to the profession by getting involved in professional bodies, participating in mentorship programs, or even becoming a faculty member at a recognized institution. Sharing your knowledge and experience not only benefits aspiring accountants but also allows you to leave a lasting impact on the profession.

Remember, the path you choose after becoming a CA is unique to your goals, interests, and aspirations. It's essential to stay adaptable, continuously learn, and embrace new challenges along the way. The journey doesn't end with qualification; it's just the beginning of a lifelong commitment to professional growth and excellence!

name: Nicole Rose
about: UK & Australian Lawyer| Compliance Creativity Warrior| Author Compliance With Attitude| Compliance & Risk Adviser and Training Specialist| Artist| Podcast Co-host Eight Mindsets
description:
"I want to do something splendid... something heroic or wonderful that won't be forgotten after I'm dead. I .. mean to astonish you all someday." 
Jo March, Little Women Louisa May Alcott

That is a bold claim. And one that I think we can all can achieve.

In fact, I have devoted an entire section to this in my new book: TOLD (The Training and Engagement Guidebook for in-house Legal and Compliance professionals).
 
Extract below:

We are proud of our achievements. So many lawyers and compliance professionals I have worked with and interviewed share, with pride, that ‚Äòdeal‚Äô or 'that' time they implemented that program from scratch ‚Äì with a team of just three, or put together a workshop on a moment‚Äôs notice and brought the house down.

But when we don‚Äôt just reflect on the past but focus on our work having a lasting impact for our audience now and in the future, that‚Äôs when we turn our work into a mission.

And my greatest success in doing this has not been due to just my hard work, knowledge, experience, or even creativity. 

It's actually something far more practical. 

It's down to the characters in the stories that bring to life the learning moments. 

There was Jane. This avatar was lovingly created with my good friend and colleague, Jason Meyer. We brought her into the board room as a slightly naive, ready to impress, experienced financial controller who was taking on her first board position.

When we first meet Jane, we see her packing up her office with a leaving card beside her. We then see her sitting at her home desk with a cup of steaming black coffee reading her board papers whilst children (we assume these are her grandchildren) are laughing and playing in the garden outside. We hear the sound of laughter and classical music.

Jane's setting was intentional. We imagine her to be a grandma, someone well respected in her old workplace and an intellect who listens to classical music whilst she works. We can imagine her humming. 

That scene design was Jason‚Äôs genius. He made Jane human because we needed people to relate to her. The audience needed to empathise with her and go on her journey to learn the small but important differences between what is required of a senior executive compared to a board member. 

It worked. Jane was part of a five part series and we were asked to produce another a year later. Jane became immortal.

Jane was imagined from the type of audience we were aiming at. Someone new to the board, ambitious and learning. She was our avatar.

An avatar is the starting point of making our work outlast us.

You don't need to be a script writer or artist to design your own 'Jane'. 
You have the experience to know, understand and relate first-hand to your audience. 

So, why not create a character your audience will relate to and use it in your next presentation or training session? If you do your job well, they may even see themselves in it. 

And it you want help with the design - just DM me.

name: Mark Stovel, CPA
about: Helping Accountants Take Home $250K+ A YearüöÄ | Firm Nexus | Fractional CFO
description:
After 1.5 years as a financial controller,
an HR consultant‚Äôs question blew my mind.

I was working for a manufacturing company and
the production manager gave his 2 weeks notice.

The HR consultant was helping us fill the role,
and, after a short convo, she asked if I wanted the role.

Her question challenged two limiting assumptions:
1. Could I learn new skills outside formal education?
2. As a CPA, could I offer value in non-traditional role?

I told her I was interested in the position.

We spoke to the owner, and the next week I started
as the operations controller with a 17-person team.

That push by the HR consultant helped me 
take my side hustle full-time over a year later.

If you‚Äôre on the fence about starting a firm,
don‚Äôt let bad assumptions about skills stop you.

No one starts a firm with all the skills.

If you have a CPA, you can start a firm.
Not because of the CPA, but the process to get it.

The first or next stage of growth in your firm
is just on the other side of a few new skills.

name: Devashish Paul
about: CEO and Founder, BluWave-ai, Tech Innovator, Ironman Athlete, Military Veteran
description:
Like anything in life your base level of ability you can bank on is what you practice 10000 times.

The goal in repeating whatever it is (could be calculus, play guitar, serving tennis balls , writing code, following up with customers) is we bring our lowest performance up. Michael Phelps' lowest.performance was in the medals. His peak performances were world records.

Peak performance comes from 8-12 weeks of sharpening after years of elevating the base level that we can bank on 

Further to this we can only control our performance not the performance of others. who else shows up we cannot control. We can only control ourselves.

I was talking to one of my angel investors Michael Fedele and saying the role of a startup CEO is to raise the lowest level of performance of our teams this is the performance we can take to bank every one of 365 days. Gradually we need to lift it so the team is a playoff contender and playing for championships.

Later I was talking to my VP of Finance Muhammad Zaheed, MBA . He was beating himself up because he felt he did not bring his A game to work one day. I said, 'It is impossible to bring peak performance to the line daily, what we need from the entire team is you give today's A game even though today you have factors that don't allow you to bring your absolute peak...I don't need your absolute best daily, I need today's best'.

So last summer I was in 'peak condition' trying to qualify for the The IRONMAN Group 70.3 world's in 2024 in New Zealand in my 55-59 age group. In a hard battle over 113km I lost the final slot to a superior athlete in the last kilometer. I was empty and lost by 80 seconds.

But you can't control who shows up. I did my best that day in July 2023 and it was insufficient.

Back to the drawing board to see if I can qualify but one more year means being a soon to be a 59 year old in what is actually a very competitive group of 55-59 athletes from around the world.

I booked my longest vacation since starting BluWave-ai and had plans to be in peak shape for another shot at Ironman70.3 St. George Utah. But this is all a side show that allows me to practice principles of self improvement that I can in turn apply to the revenue generating part of life at work. Company goals take a primary place and then I got horribly sick in my final 8 week 'peak sharpening phase'. So I went in with my base.

It turns out some faster guys in my age group had already qualified at other races and I was in position to snatch good luck after 5:34 of racing in the heat and hills of Utah. 

When I coached soccer I used to tell the team that what matters is what you do when the coach is not looking. 

I never take lunch...I pack some sandwiches and train every day at lunch... and from 8-10pm when there are less obligations I end up training in the basement or gym...would be easy to skip it and go to bed. And with that I start my 40th year in triathlon, Year one was age 19, in 1985

name: Nuria Richards
about: Director of Development, Locust Projects | President, ArtTable
description:
Dear ArtTable Community, 
As the new President of the Board of ArtTable, I am honored for the opportunity to support an organization dedicated to advancing the careers of women-identifying and nonbinary professionals in the visual arts. I step into this role as the first Latina immigrant holding such a big responsibility and am grateful to have served this community locally as part of the Florida Chapter before and during challenging lockdown times, and most recently as VP of Finance.
I firmly believe that our community's strength lies in its leadership and diversity, reflected in the dedication of our staff, several generations of outstanding members, and our devoted returning and new board members. Felice Axelrod will assume the role of Vice President. We are welcoming five incoming members: Sierra Van Ryck deGroot, Laura Doyle, Jane Glassman, Amy Oppio, and Lavita McMath Turner.
Dorothy D√°vila has been appointed Chair of Finance. Delphine Daniels was appointed Chair of Development, Kat Griefen will continue to chair the Membership and Inclusivity Committee, and Laura Bardier will maintain her position as Chair of Governance. You can find out more about all of our current board members by clicking on their photos on our website here.
I encourage each and every one of you to actively embrace the position you hold as part of this community. Those of you starting your careers are the inspiration of our Fellowship Program, a program open to emerging professionals from cultural, racial, ethnic, and/or socio-economic backgrounds underrepresented in our field.
For those of you who have strengthened your career paths and ask yourselves what else can be done, I invite you to find inspiration in our Pay Equity and Career Development Initiatives; your involvement and collaboration are key for the continuity of valuable exchanges of ideas. In this day and age, gender-based wage gaps impact poverty in retirement and especially impact those with children. At ArtTable, we address this through building strong networks of opportunity within and beyond our industry, and through research and advocacy. Our next public discussion about the findings of the ArtTable Survey on Working in the Arts in October will continue to advance pay equity research for arts professionals, artists, and arts workers of all types. I look forward to supporting environments that allow our community to relieve itself from gender-generated distress.
...
I look forward to seeing all of you participating in our programs, mentoring, and adopting professional camaraderie and support as a life initiative; remember sharing a spot at the table will make a big difference. Finally, I want to thank all the individuals, foundations, corporations, and agencies that support ArtTable and help carry our initiatives to a successful landing.
Thank you for your support,
Nuria Richards,
Board President

name: John Schmidt
about: Headhunter
description:
Which opportunity would you have accepted?

I spoke with a company in a very rural community recently and was doing so because they're starting up a new facility and looking for someone to lead finance.

They mentioned to me the position is critical because they had a turndown.

I know the person that turned them down so I called her to inquire. If there has ever been a bad hiring process, this was it. I almost can't believe it.

Company A
> Two Teams meetings, never saw a company facility
> Corporate Recruiter
> Plant Manager
> Another person in finance (a higher up)
> Timeframe: 2 months
> Received an offer letter after she told them she was getting an offer from Company B
> Salary: Higher
> Commute: Same but also same time zone
> Industry: Same industry

Company B
> Teams meeting
> Flew her to West Coast to see another plant
> Took her to lunch
> Met CEO 
> Met VP Finance
> Met Operations Director
> Timeframe: 3 weeks
> Salary: Lower
> Intangible: more personable, everyone was really excited, excited to open new facility, process was good, made me feel valued
> Commute: same but different time zone
> Industry: never worked in it

She joined Company B. Literally went to work in a different time zone for less money in a new industry because of how botched this was. Your hiring process is costing your company lots of money.

about: 720 followers
description:
Urban Engineering | DCCM is excited to announce the promotions of both Anthony Allen and Doug Lawrence, P.E.! Starting July 1st, Anthony elevated to Vice President - Director of Business Development and Doug will be elevated to Director of Operations.
 
Anthony joined Urban Engineering in May 2021 as a Project Manager. Prior to joining Urban Engineering, Anthony worked in the oil and gas energy industry for 8 years as a field engineer, project manager, site supervisor and consultant for companies such as Exxon, XTO and Halliburton. Since joining Urban, Anthony has been the Program Director for over a dozen FEMA and EDA funded projects in Port Aransas delivering the projects on schedule and within budget. We look forward to the growth and expansion of the company through Anthony‚Äôs efforts to improve existing client relationships and to add new clients and opportunities.
 
Doug Lawrence joined Urban Engineering | DCCM in March of this year and immediately showed his value as a leader and coordinator with the engineering staff, improving staff and client communications and improving the quality of work being produced. Doug has over 35 years of experience and proven performance in both civil and structural engineering. We are pleased to promote Doug to the Director of Operations position and look forward to his success at expanding and managing our staff and improving our efficiency and the quality of our work.
 
Please join us in congratulating Anthony and Doug on their well-deserved promotions!

As I wrap up my first week at Charlie Health, my head is stirring with new information and my heart is so full knowing the impact we make each day!

Did you know 85% of Americans have no access to mental health treatment when needed the most? Due to barriers such as, location, cost, facility, and correct clinician/treatment.

Charlie Health offers a life-saving solution with the first ever virtual intensive outpatient program for high acuity patients. name: Redberry Restaurants
about: 6,882 followers
description:
Kulwinder More is celebrating a milestone. We are so proud of her story. It is one of a new immigrant who chartered her own path to success. She is a testament of the power of determination, resilience and the unwavering support of a company that truly values its employee‚Äôs growth and well-being.

Congratulations on 25 years, Kulwinder!

‚ÄúWhen I immigrated to Canada 27 years ago, my goal was to continue pursuing a career in law. However, upon arrival, I realized that becoming a lawyer in Canada would require an additional four years of study, which I couldn‚Äôt afford as a newcomer. As the years went by, I became a busy Mom and sought a part-time job that would allow me to be with my kids. I approached a Pizza Hut and was hired to assist during lunch buffets, thus starting my journey with the brand. I continued in this role for several years, prioritizing my family over career advancement. As my children grew and entered full-time schooling, I decided to refocus on my career. I accepted a Shift Manager position and eventually worked my way up to Assistant Manager. With determination and hard work, I was promoted to Restaurant General Manager, then District Manager, and eventually rose to the position of Regional Manager and Director of Operations for Pizza Hut and now Taco Bell.‚Äù

name: Jim Louderback
about: Creator Economy Sherpa | Award Winning Curator, Moderator & Speaker | "Inside the Creator Economy" Newsletter | Board of Director | Geek
description:
UPDATE - Just because there's a new president doesn't mean the old one is going anywhere. Marc Hustvedt is still President too!

Every LinkedIn profile tells a story.

I don‚Äôt know MrBeast‚Äôs new President Jeffrey Housenbold - so let's do a LinkedIn Profile Unboxing and see what we can learn. 

Starting with the experience section.

He‚Äôs been busy, with 55 positions listed. 

If you toss the first 5 - which includes a McDonalds internship - there are only 3 operating roles in last 50.

He spent four years running marketing and BD at eBay - and left in 2005 to take the CEO job at Shutterfly. Over 11 years, he took it public and drove substantial growth.

After leaving in 2016 he spent five years ias a founding partner at Mega-VC Softbank and joining the board of 20+ companies. 

After a brief 11-month stint as Leaf CEO ‚Äì where he tried and failed to take the gutter protection company public, he started his own venture firm, racking up more investments and board seats.

And in May he became President and Chief Operating Officer of MrBeast ‚Äì or as he says in his announcement post ‚ÄúMr Beast Industries‚Äù.

Aside, did they bury the story by announcing right after MrBeast passed T-series as the most subscribed YouTube channel?

He‚Äôs also listed as Co-Owner of ‚ÄúKirk‚Äôs Steakburgers‚Äù in Palo Alto, CA, but I can‚Äôt see him running the kitchen. Likely just the money guy.

The recommendation section shows he approved 15 recommendations from former staffers but wrote just one ‚Äì 10 years ago.

He also lists himself as author of ‚ÄúThe Shutterfly Guide to Great Digital Photos,‚Äù but I assume it was mostly written by his co-author Dave Johnson.

And he follows 8 newsletters on LinkedIn including Gina Bianchini‚Äôs ‚ÄúPurpose‚Äù, but the others are mostly investment related. 

Interestingly he's subscribed to ‚ÄùCannabis Index‚Äù, which should go over well if he moves to North Carolina. 

Hint, Jeffrey, subscribe to ‚ÄúInside the Creator Economy‚Äù. But leave the weed at home.

What can we learn? 

üîªHe‚Äôs a Silicon Valley insider who‚Äôs seen success and failure (typical), raised billions, and taken a startup to IPO. 

üîªNo media or creator investing/operating experience, aside from a board stint at Chegg and Digital Chocolate.

My thoughts:

üîªThere‚Äôs not a great history of non-media execs taking over creator-type companies (see Whitman, Meg and Quibi). But there‚Äôs always a first time. 

üîªIs this a signal that could lead to a trend?

üîªMrBeast execs are typically forced to move to North Carolina. If so, will a ‚ÄúKirk‚Äôs BBQ‚Äù open soon in New Bern.

üîª‚ÄúMrBeast Industries‚Äù is a heady vision. 

The real question is how will this SV tech-bro mesh with a company mostly run by Mr. Beast, his brother and his mom.

üëá What do you think about Mr. Beast‚Äôs new President and COO? Mold-breaker or culture clash?

Oh, and perhaps take a look at the story YOUR LI profile tells - before it gets unboxed too.
‚Ä¶see more

name: American Banker
about: 183,901 followers
description:
Several Fifth Third Bank executives will have new responsibilities after ringing in the new year.

The moves included naming Tim Spence, CEO of the Cincinnati, Ohio, bank, as chairman starting Jan. 2. The bank‚Äôs board members also approved the promotion of Chief Financial Officer Jamie Leonard to chief operating officer.

Replacing Leonard as CFO will be Bryan Preston, who has worked at Fifth Third for nearly two decades and currently serves as the bank‚Äôs treasurer. Brennen Willingham will take the treasurer position after serving as the bank‚Äôs managing director for capital, liquidity and corporate development.

The bank‚Äôs executive leadership under Spence is continuing to execute on a vision for Fifth Third that began during the tenure of former CEO Greg Carmichael, who retired from the bank in July 2022, Piper Sandler analyst Scott Siefers said in an interview.

‚ÄúAcross the board, they get high marks for the transformation that Fifth Third has undergone over the last several years,‚Äù Siefers said. ‚ÄúThe bank has gone in a lot of different directions, which has set the company up for success, no matter the externalities.

about: Executive Officer & Official Photographer (Free Lance) at 3i3s-Europa ‚ñ∫ Aerospace/Aeronautical/Defence/CyberSpace ‚ñ∫ personality portraitist üé¨
description:
The best way to counter bad artificial intelligence is using good AI
By Andrew Makridis - C4ISRNET

Could terrorists or other bad actors use artificial intelligence to create a deadly pandemic? Scientists at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology conducted an experiment to find out last year.
Researchers asked a group of students, none of whom had specialized training in the life sciences, to use AI tools, such as OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT-4, to develop a plan for how to start a pandemic. In just an hour, participants learned how to procure and synthesize deadly pathogens like smallpox in ways that evade existing biosecurity systems.
AI cannot yet manufacture a national security crisis. As Jason Matheny at Rand reiterates, while biological know-how is becoming more widely accessible through AI, it‚Äôs not currently at a level that would substitute for a lack of biological research training. But as biotechnology becomes both more advanced -- think of Google DeepMind‚Äôs AlphaFold, which uses AI to predict how molecular structures will interact -- policymakers are understandably worried that it‚Äôll be increasingly easy to create a bioweapon. So they‚Äôre starting to take action to regulate the emerging AI industry.
Their efforts are well-intentioned. But it‚Äôs critical that policymakers avoid focusing too narrowly on catastrophic risk and inadvertently hamstring the creation of positive AI tools that we need to tackle future crises. We should aim to strike a balance.
AI tools have enormous positive potential. For instance, AI technologies like AlphaFold and RFdiffusion have already made large strides in designing novel proteins that could be used for medical purposes. The same sort of technologies can also be used for evil, of course.
In a study published last year in the journal Nature Machine Intelligence, researchers demonstrated how the AI MegaSyn could generate 40,000 potential bioweapon chemicals in just six hours. Researchers asked the AI to identify molecules that are similar to VX, a highly lethal nerve agent. In some cases, MegaSyn devised compounds that were even more toxic.
It‚Äôs possible that bad actors could one day use such tools to engineer new pathogens far more contagious and deadly than any occurring in nature. Once a potential bioweapon is identified -- maybe with the help of AI -- a malicious actor could order a custom strand of DNA from a commercial provider, who would manufacture synthetic DNA in a lab and return it via mail. As experts at the Center for Security and Emerging Technology at Georgetown University has posited, perhaps that strand of genetic material ‚Äúcodes for a toxin or a gene that makes a pathogen more dangerous.
It‚Äôs even possible that a terrorist could evade detection by ordering ... ‚§µ ‚§µ ‚§µ

- Andrew Makridis is the former Chief Operating Officer of the CIA, the number-three position at the agency. Prior to his retirement from the CIA in 2022, he spent nearly four decades working in national security.

name: Aviva August Rayne
about: Newcastle Law School Alumna/ Civil Servant at Ministry of Justice
description:
In her letter written to Edmund Burke in 1790 to respond to Burke's Reflections on the Revolution in France , Marry Wollstonecraft, a women's rights advocate put "Every thing looks like a means, nothing like an end, and now let us sit down and enjoy the present moment; our faculties and wishes are proportioned to the present scene". 

Taken out of context, these words conjure up the notion of carpe diem. Yet, she is quite the opposite by making a century long educational plan for women at the time to be considered as an intrinsic being, rather than a mere property. The reason why she suggests the above excerpt is because she intends to calm down Burke's fear of an emulation of the French Revolution in England echoing the English Jacobins' concerns, not that she cares much for, though. Why did I quote it then? Soon, will you find out. Better still, it will make sense more in the future. 

Fast forward to 2024, I met incredible people at Cabinet Office (CO) for the past six months. First of all, the level of humility and sense of humour is such that one day you could be sitting at a desk next to a deputy director, the other day a Chief Operating Officer who visits offices around the country. Most importantly, they'd strike a conversation in a manner with you like a normal employee and unless you know them, you will never know what their grade is. As you know in Britain, we long gave up addressing people of higher grades/positions with such archaic terms like 'Sir/Madam' unless they were knighted. Everybody from top to bottom is called with their first name, even in emails, irrespective of who they are. 

The second commendable culture that CO fosters is that the wide range of support and guidance offered for individuals' learning and self- development, again regardless of what grade you are at. Hence, if you are considering working in civil service but you also value self-development in your career, look no further. 

And finally, a second to none team culture, or should I say a family-like team culture. In addition to the work-related help and support, the teams' social meets, which are usually cognitive, (once a month or so) are part of the package too. After all, if you do not enhance/retain the team's bonding, your workplace would be a tedious and hostile place culminating in unchecked arrogance between seniors and juniors. 

My lovely team organised a surprise leaving party for me as seen in the picture with some exquisite presents to which I am indebted. You can see the sense of humour there. Although I will cherish the moments I spent working alongside my team, I will now sit down and enjoy my faculties and wishes being proportioned to the present time. Because, for me, everything is a means, not an end. 

With that in mind, I look forward to starting my new role at MoJ on Monday which will be an invaluable experience for me.

name: Ravi Bhatia
about: Empowering Organizations through Technology Leadership || Engineering head at CerebrumX
description:
üëâ Building a Technology Team from Scratch: A Step-by-Step Guide üí™ 

When starting a new venture or scaling your business, setting up a technology team plays a crucial role in driving innovation and achieving success. In this post, I'll outline the key steps to establish a robust technology team, including the required roles, number of resources, experience levels, chronology order, and the overall time it takes to build the team.

1. Define Your Goals and Objectives:
 Clearly articulate your business goals and technology requirements. Identify the specific areas where a technology team is essential for achieving those goals.

2. Start with Core Roles:
 Begin by hiring core team members who will lay the foundation for your technology initiatives. This typically includes roles like a CTO (Chief Technology Officer), software engineers, and a project manager.

3. Expand the Team as Needed:
 As your business grows, gradually expand the team to include specialists in areas such as UI/UX design, data analytics, quality assurance, and infrastructure management. Assess your needs based on your business requirements and market trends.

4. Determine Resource Allocation:
 Determine the number of resources needed for each role based on the scale and complexity of your projects. Consider factors like project workload, timelines, and the level of expertise required.

5. Seek Experience and Expertise:
 Balance the experience levels within your team. A mix of seasoned professionals and talented individuals early in their careers can bring a fresh perspective and drive innovation while ensuring a strong foundation of knowledge.

6. Establish Chronology Order:
 Consider the logical progression of roles within your technology team. For example, start with hiring a CTO to provide strategic guidance, followed by software engineers to build the core product, and then expand into specialized areas like data analytics or UI/UX design.

7. Time to Build:
 The time required to build a technology team varies based on your specific needs and available resources. On average, it may take several months to assemble a fully functional team, considering the recruitment process, onboarding, and integration.

Remember, building a technology team is not just about filling positions. It's about finding the right individuals who align with your vision, possess the necessary skills, and can collaborate effectively to achieve your business goals.

By following these steps and carefully structuring your technology team, you can lay a solid foundation for success and ensure your business remains agile, innovative, and competitive in the ever-evolving digital landscape.

name: Thayz Figueir√™do
about: Sports Psychologist | Mental Health Care | Gender Equality | Safeguarding | Active Listening | Communication | Respect for Diversity |
description:
"5. A revolution in women's sports will take shape

In 2024, women athletes will see financial gains and be placed on a more equal footing with their male counterparts, starting with football and extending across sports, leagues and borders.

This year's FIFA Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand made clear that women's sports has an audience to be reckoned with. Viewership soared globally and attendance records for the event were crushed. The record-breaking viewership, as well as a burgeoning fan culture on social media, has drawn the keen eye of sponsors. Expect bigger endorsements for star athletes.

We should also expect institutional changes, with more stringent rules on how women are treated on and off the field. The World Cup's "me too" moment, which culminated in the resignation of Spanish football federation president Luis Rubiales ‚Äì followed by a three-year-ban from all football activities at national and international levels ‚Äì sent a clear message that change is long overdue. Expect a new wave of women stepping into leadership roles as coaches and administrators. At this year's event, just 12 out of 32 teams had a woman coach.

These changes will be further solidified at the Paris Olympics this summer. For the first time, the Summer Olympics will feature a 50/50 split of male and female athletes. 

Up next: We'll see more women serving as Olympic coaches. Women have accounted for a mere 10% of coaches over the past 10 years, according to International Olympic Committee member Nawal El Moutawakel. "We need women and young girls to see female coaches, to believe that they too can achieve positions of responsibility and influence," she says. ‚Äì Cathy Anderson"

description:
I'm happy to share that I'm starting a new position as VP of Marketing at Row House!

A few reasons why I love rowing inspired fitness:

+ It's a full body workout! From the push of your legs to the brace of your core and the pull in your upper body, each stroke is a full body burn

+ Rowing is low-impact and for life. It doesn't not penalize you for your size, age, weaknesses or injuries and is, in my *non-biased opinion*, the most inclusive exercise modality

+ Row House's coaches are some of the best indoor row coaches in the country. A focus on proper form and efficiency in classes makes entry accessible for all and mastery fun, challenging, and rewarding

Curious to try a Row House class? Let me know below or shoot me a DM. LA-and OC-based connections, let's row together!

name: Melanie Borden
about: I lead a team of creative, high-performing experts who transform businesses, executives, and leaders by increasing their reach, impact, and brand marketing effectiveness | CEO @ The Borden Group
description:
Trolls can't hurt you if you don't let them.
However, they can direct you to your North Star.


Before I was on LinkedIn, I got heavily trolled in person.

It wasn't fun.

I started a new position in Jan 2018, happy as can be, and one of my first responsibilities in this new role was to audit every dollar the businesses were spending with their marketing budget and agency.

Six auto franchises
A real estate development company
A radio show &
A CEO

Five years of invoices, marketing calendars, parts statements, monthly budgets, emails, etc.

In the process, my happiness levels came crashing down.
Mainly caused by a few individuals who didn't like what I was doing. üëé

I was searching for a light at the end of the tunnel,
because it was difficult in the office and mentally
it impacted me during an already challenging time.

I was constantly on the defensive.
I wasn't eating.
I felt isolated.

I had to find ways to compartmentalize through consuming positivity,
and ways to shift my mindset.

Years later, LinkedIn entered my life at the beginning stages of the pandemic.

LinkedIn became my North Star. üåü

-I documented my day-to-day and shared strategies and tips in marketing,
-I developed relationships with people all over the world,
- I started a new position at a tech company as a VP of Marketing,
- I won a 40 under 40 award, Women in Retail Award, among dozens of podcasts, advertorials, "Top lists," and other opportunities for visibility,
-Inbound leads from executives became regular (still are)
and so on, leading to me starting my own business.

LinkedIn also has helped me become increasingly aware of those around me and their intentions.

Thanks to those angry trolls I worked with,
They led me right here ü•∞

So the next time you troll someone with your megaphone in the comments or in person, understand that you are doing that person a favor.

Have trolls shaped any of your experiences?
What is your North Star?

name: Dan Malgran
about: VP of Marketing at Steno | B2B Tech | Startup Advisor
description:
Ruminations from the first 3 weeks of a new VP of Marketing.

TL:DR: Prioritization.

It's now been about 3 weeks in the role and I've certainly learned a lot, I'll spill some of the thoughts that really stick out to me.

Fair warning, dear reader, the variations of the word "prioritize" will make a lot of appearances in this post.

1. Get yourself organized. I thought I could organize my thoughts, plans, and tasks previously, but I've had to overhaul everything. I keep a 30/60/90 in monday.com, I have a weekly task list in GSheets with To Dos, Follow-Ups, Unscheduled Asks, and Weekly Accomplishments (I can make that a template if someone wants it).

2. Meet everyone you can, and keep a little black book (*doesn't have to be black, I guess). I try to schedule very informal meet & greets with all the teams with no agenda, give and get a little personal background, share my initial thoughts, and get their "big asks" from marketing. We're all over the country here, so I also note where everyone's located.

3. The things you thought you would prioritize before starting will immediately change, and that's ok. Be flexible to the landscape and adjust accordingly. I assumed my first hire would be Content, but I quickly pivoted to a Product Marketing Manager (heads up: I'm 
hashtag
#hiring, will drop the link in the comments). 

4. Listen to calls, and listen to team breakdowns of calls. You'll learn a lot very quickly, both of what prospects are asking and how your sales team is pitching. You can't align if you don't understand their process.

5. Lean on your network. If you have mentor-like people, run ideas by them. I've even run "how do I position this new role properly" by them. You're not alone out there, even when you're a Lonely Marketer (h/t JK Sparks newsletter). 

6. Be strict about your prioritization. You can't do everything, even if it all seems necessary. Delegate what you can (if you have the team) and don't be afraid to push things back to get foundations in place. Don't build your department on a foundation of "I'm trying to get everything done immediately."

7. It is a-ok to say "no". Moving up from Manager to Director to VP, this shift may have been the hardest. You can, should, and need to say no to people. There are only so many hours in the day, and only so much bandwidth you and your team have. Not all asks are a priority. 

8. The LinkedIn community is great and I have probably 100 saved posts here. This seems very important: Not all advice, frameworks, or "best practices" apply to you, your company, or your industry. You need to know your situation and know when those practices won't work.

9. Be excited and have fun. Ship something interesting early. Keep the excitement going, you're gonna do great! 

Anyway, more to come!
